prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Hollow Grind on an O1 Blade

At whirring dusktime swarfling motes
went whizzle down the bay;
All burrful bent the benchwise brood,
to whet the workroom day.

“Beware the Burrbogle, my child—
shun Skitter-shears and skrews;
It nicks the knurls and gnaws the mild,
and drinks the temper’s dews.”

He raised his O1 hollow-blade
to stones that hissed and sang;
He hollow-ground till swarf-smoke flowed—
ker-snick, ker-snak, ker-slang.

He stood beside the anvil-elm
in grumbleminded muse;
He stilled the jitter in his helm
and eyed the filings’ blues.

Then burring came the Burrbogle
with clack and scuddle-scrape;
Its bevel-breath blew bitter flame
through quench-cold shopfloor drape.

One hollow hew—O1 sang true;
skree-skraw the burrs flew wide;
He wheel-walked in, then shear-swept through,
and split its scuttle-side.

He shopward strode, the blade still bright,
a sack upon his back;
The master cried, “Well-won, O wright!”
The clamps went clap-clap-clack.

At whirring dusktime swarfling motes
still whizzle down the bay;
No burrful bend the benchwise brood—
the Burrbogle’s away.

info.topic: hollow grind on an O1 blade

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Forged Leaf Scroll

At tallow dusk the forgeleaf trees
Did whorl and whisk the scribing air,
All vellum-vine in copper breeze,
And hush fell over there.

“Beware the Scrollgraul, tender sprout,”
My elder said, brow inked with care;
“The filigreed and fangèd snout
Goes crinkle in its lair.

Take hold of the nickeltine seax,
And bind your bracer, buckle fair;
For pergafume and smear of wax,
And mind the codex glare.

I strode through scrollwood, candle-quick,
The quill-winds whistled, thin as hair;
The brazenfoils went clicka-click,
Skree-skree from hidden lairs.

Forth slumped the Scrollgraul, page-gnawed vast,
Its lampblack drool made puddles glare;
With crinkled scales of filings cast,
It chuffed a sooty blare.

It smelt the forged leaf scroll I sought,
And thrummed its cords: krang-kerr-karr, loud;
My sinews sang with steely thought—
I whispered, “Not too loud.”

Then up I sprang through smoky air,
A snick-snap seax went flaring bright;
I penned it back with circling care—
K’ching-k’char—so bright tonight.

The Scrollgraul slumped like hammered stone;
I drew the forged leaf scroll from there;
Its sigils breathed a tempered tone,
Hooom—like anviled prayer.

I paced him back through scrollwood lanes;
He laughed three times—huzza! take care;
We sealed the leaf with quenching rains,
Then hung it to the air.

At tallow dusk the forgeleaf trees
Now murmur, shimmer—inked and fair;
All vellum-vine in cooling breeze,
And hush falls everywhere.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiln witness cone bend". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Conebend Wyrm

In kilnlight, clayscape softly chimed,
And witness-cones prepared to bend;
The shardshade stirred; the slip was primed,
While fluewinds flicked their ember-send.

“Heed Conebend Wyrm,” the potter said,
“It singes sense and swallows dread;
Its glazegrin gnaws the tallest cone,
Keep kiln-calm; never go alone.”

I donned my sootkin gloves and hood,
My tongsword, quench-etched, lightly rang,
With slipwised chalk upon the wood,
I marked the cone I meant to fang.

Hiss-hush the kilnmouth breathed a tune,
The stoke-throat thumped, ka-chunk, ka-choom,
The flareskates skirled around the flue,
And clinker-clicks went clack-a-bloom.

Out coiled the Conebend Wyrm of Heat,
With glazeaze eyes and sootfelt wings;
It slither-sang, “Your cones are sweet,
I bend them, blend them, brittle things.”

I damper-dashed; the draft went shy,
I tongswiped through its crackle-mirth,
Shsh-shank! the flameskew veered awry,
And cone stood true, not bent to earth.

It hissed a kiln-keen cinder-cry,
And whip-whoomp wagged its ashwhale tail;
I tossed a glazeseed, popped it dry,
The Wyrm went dim in fume and flail.

Clink-clank, my shardstaff split its grin,
I quenched the spark within its throat;
The Conebend wracked, curled kilnwards in,
Then slumped to slag, a sleepish boat.

I strode back out through sootsoft dawn,
My tongsword soothed its ember-ache,
“The witness-cone stands straight, not drawn,
The kiln is calm; the clays won’t break.”

In kilnlight, clayscape softly chimed,
The fluewinds learned a gentler bend,
The shardshade slept; the slip was primed,
And witness-cones forgot to bend.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Urushi Lacquer Cure

At humidhour the lacquer lay,
In muro-murk and glossy gloom;
The sap sang soft of stick and stay,
While dewlets dimpled in the room.

Take heed, said Older Thorn-of-Hands,
The Vernishade is rash and sly;
It lurks where glossmire meets the bands,
And loves a careless knuckle's cry.

So mask your muzzle, glove your grip,
Mix thin the nightblack sapsap brew;
With hera-paddle, flick and drip,
And build humidarium, too.

Let water whisper, bowls brim blue,
Tok-tok the frame, now close it slight;
Hush-humid winds begin to mew,
As sheen-motes murmur into night.

Then slip-slip creeps the Vernishade,
Glossgoblin of the cure-crypt air;
It slurks along the bevelled blade
And blurps a blisome, bindish snare.

Whick-whick the sable brush I ran,
So feather-thin the shineward sweep;
Eschew the greed of gob and can—
One breath too thick, the rash will creep.

It sprang with stick and suck and spit,
Skreek-skrak went sap in snaggle-wrath;
I set the muro latch to it,
And sealed its cling within the bath.

By morrow-mist the cure was sure,
The bowl flashed calm as moon on pool;
I bore it back through muro-mure,
And Older Thorn-of-Hands said, "Cool."

At humidhour the lacquer lies,
In muro-murk and glossy gloom;
So craft and care make curings wise,
While dewlets dimple in the room.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plum brown blueing bath". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Plum Brown Blueing Bath

In plum-brown, blueing bath they bray,
the brubbles bloon and brathe and sway;
Blue steamlets swurl the siller bath,
Plumbrownness pools in blueing bath.

Take heed the Bluthergath, dear sprout;
the suds-snake Snurl and sliver-slipe;
the Gloamertub that gulps the stout—
shun swirlitor and drain-mouth gripe.

He took his latherlance of birch
and buckled on the loofa-guard;
he primed the plug with plash and lurch,
then waited, bath-brave, breathing hard.

Hush—glub-glub-glub—the drain-throat boomed;
the Bluthergath uncoiled its mane;
its eyes were rings of rinsing gloom,
it slobbered suds and sang the drain.

Skreek-skraak it scraped the porcelain
and thrumbled through the brubble-brine;
O hush my heart, the tublights thin—
the tap-knobs knocked a clocket line.

He leapt with loofalash aloft,
swish-swash! the sudder-scepter sang;
clack-CLACK! the plug was jerked and coughed—
the whirl went whee and down it sprang.

The Bluthergath went glottle-gray,
its bruxing maw grew meek and thin;
it dwindled down the spiral way,
ker-SLOOP!—a hush of hollow din.

Back through the steam he strode to home,
the elder grinned with bristle-pride;
O tub-bright joy, O scenter-foam!
You drained the dread that dreamed the tide.

In plum-brown, blueing bath they play,
brubbles bloom, brathe, and softly sway;
no Gath now gnaws the gentle bath,
and taps go tunk-tunk, soft as math.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Ink-Brayer and Chase

When gutter lamps in formes did glow,
and galleys groaned in grease;
The sorts went susurr-sifted slow,
ink whispered piece by piece.

Beware the Blotterghast, take heed,
the Skreekle-smearlings bite;
That Splatchling stalks where chases bleed,
and blot the page to night.

He gripped his ink-brayer and brace,
clicked quoins about the chase;
Clack-clack went quoinkey, clamp and place,
he rolled a steady face.

Through tympan gloom the Smudgewight slid;
skreek-skrak its tendrils sang;
It splutter-slosh’d with inky lid,
and blot-breath, bang by bang.

He whirr-whacked with the brayer-rod;
the Smudgewight screeched, sss-hee!
A squeegee-swipe, a sudden prod,
and smutch gave up its hiss.

He bore his brayer home again,
through galleys, grins, and glue;
“Ho hurrah!” the binders: Amen,
“Your forme prints clean and true!”

When gutter lamps in formes yet glow,
and galleys hum in grease;
The sorts go sifted, supple-slow,
ink whispers piece by piece.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "summit prayer flag". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Summit Prayer Flag

Cloud-early blew the banner-wind,
The prayerflags snapped; cords ka-ching.
And frostlings twinkled up the rind,
As yodelgusts went whish-whish-sing.

Take heed the Clutchdrake's glacier glare;
Its lip-latch snaps; it grapples fast.
Avoid the Skreegrim, lean of mast,
And fear the yaksong thunderblast.

He cinched his ropes of prayer-thread,
A flintbright serac-shearing glaive;
And donned the stormhood eiderfine,
For gust and ghost and creviced cave.

Up switchback spines he step by step,
The prayerflags clapped: flap-flap, clap.
The snow-sun stung, the breath went pep,
And tinkled pegs went kip-kip-kap.

From scree and shadow Skreegrim sprang,
A snowlash tail, a grindstone tongue;
It whirred and whickered: krang-krang-krang,
Its breath a churn of incense-slung.

He set his boot on ice-slick grit,
And raised the serac-shearing steel;
One sidestep, slip, a skyrill flit—
Then snick! the Skreegrim reeled to kneel.

He carved the knot of rime and scale,
Its gullet chimed with clatter-snow;
Down tumbled fang and frost-blue mail,
Hush-hush the flaglines slackened slow.

He hiked the last white rib to crest,
And raised his threadbare wish to sky;
Flags smote the wind's broad chest with zest,
And boom! the yodelgust did cry.

Down switchbacks, past the yak-bell ring,
They wrapped his chill in buttered tea;
The old ones thrummed the corded string,
And hummed the sky-knot litany.

Cloud-even sings the banner-wind,
The prayerflags snap; cords ka-ching.
While frostlings twinkle up the rind,
And yodelgusts go whish-whish-sing.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Soundpost-Setter and the Wolfnote Wyrm

In varnishvale the grainways groaned,
and bow-buzz brimmed the dusky air;
The f-hole fen in maple moaned,
click-clack of clamps kept time in there.

Heed me, apprentice, whispered wise,
a Wolfnote Wyrm lies tightly coiled;
Shun squeakerghasts with resin eyes;
their scree and saw leave benches soiled.

He grabbed his soundpost setter-spear,
a shivershard for tonewood keel;
With pegwhirl mutter in his ear,
a temperbrightened length of steel.

Through f-hole fen he slid the prong,
tap-tap went sprucey skin within;
The Wolfnote Wyrm uncoiled in song,
skreek-skraw! from belly's darkling din.

He braced the post by grainlight's guide,
thwip-thunk! the setter gripped on fast;
He stilled the snarl of bowward tide,
ping-plunk! the wolfnote drifted past.

Back through the shop he step-sprung light,
the rosinreeks grew warm and sweet;
Luthier nodded ruddy-bright,
"Tone-tamer, take your patient seat."

In varnishvale the grainways hummed,
and bow-buzz gentled dusky air;
The f-hole fen lay rest-ensummed,
click-clack kept softer time in there.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "night‑blooming cereus vigil". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Night-Blooming Cereus Vigil

At midnight in the cactus close,
a hush lay rich and spare in air;
the mothlings kept their amber doze,
and dewbeads prinked the spines with glare.

Beware the Ceregeist, my sprout,
whose hush is honeyed dread at night;
it lures with musk and lantern-spout,
then tangles heart and head in night.

He gripped his moonclip pruner-bright,
and lit a glimble lantern damp;
he paced the beds till pulse was right,
then kept his cerevigil camp.

He waited by the spiny post,
and chirr-chirr wings went whirring lace;
the night-bloom bud made moonward boast,
its petals poured like folded lace.

Out from the musk the Ceregeist
came sip-sip, pale and sly of eye;
its lamping nodules pearled with mist,
and sweetness fogged the sky awry.

I flashed the moonclip, snip-snap-snip,
and pared the Shadowvine in twain;
its strangly loops lost grip and slip,
the bud drew breath through hidden vein.

I hurried through the beds again,
with petals' moon to show and share;
"My bloom-bold bud!" the elder's strain,
"your watch has gentled garden air."

At midnight in the cactus close,
a hush lies rich and spare in air;
the mothlings keep their amber doze,
and dewbeads prink the spines with flare.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Cassette Wow and Flutter

Wind-warm the walkman whirred and wound,
The spindles softly sway;
Tape-oxides dreamt in dusking sound,
With wow and flutter play.

"Heed now," the lintwise Oracule,
"Beware Wowfluther-whirr;
The warble-worm with wobble tread,
And hissling Shredder-purr."

He grabbed his splice-keen silver blade,
Demag-rod, bias-charm,
A capstan key, a felt-pad aid,
To steady reel from harm.

He wound the whippled leader straight,
Click-clack the casing spoke;
The pinch-rollered gates of dark fate
Went skritch and sss and croak.

Out from the tape's dim ferric lane,
With waver-waffled roar,
The Wowfluther shimmied, with strain,
Its hum a hungry "warrr."

Its ribbon-ribs went rick-a-rack,
It looped in lurch and loll,
It pitch-bent breaths to brake him back,
With wow-whee, whirr, and yawl.

Then quick he set the azimuth,
He smoothed the stretchling seam;
Snap-snack! the splice-keen silver tooth
Cut through the warble-dream.

The Wowfluther gave flutter-sigh,
A dwindled droning tone;
It spooled to stillness, thin and dry,
Like dust on microphone.

He brought the case back, clasped and clean,
To Mender of the Deck;
"O ferric joy! O chrome-bright sheen!"
They hummed and tapped the tech.

Wind-warm the walkman whirred and wound,
The spindles steady, true;
No wow, no flutter, only sound,
And memories sang through.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "opal play‑of‑color flash". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
Opal Play-of-Color Flash

At glimmercroon the opals chimed,
And flary flints in flumen splash;
All chromy-cleft the prisms climbed
Through play-of-color's opal flash.

Mind Flashopalax now, young child—
The glare-gnash, prism-fanged and sly—
That glimmergob grows giddy-wild
And woos with opaled lullaby.

He donned his shadehood, nightward knit,
And strapped the rainbokeenish brand;
His prishelm fit; his gloamgrit wit
Set steady for the Shimmersland.

Hush-hushing went the pebble-brooks,
Skreek-skrawked the thin selene weed;
Then whirrish through the moonlit nooks,
Flashopalax with glimmer-greed.

It flared a play-of-color glare
And shimmy-shammed sight to ash;
He swept his rainbokeenish air—
Tuk-tak! the ether-edge went slash.

Down fell the glare-gnash, prism-hide;
Its iridescent sputters died;
He bound its gleam with shadow-hide,
And in his chest the tremor died.

At glimmercroon the opals chimed;
He homeward trod through hush and splash;
All chromy-cleft his triumph timed
Through play-of-color's opal flash.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "peony ants at dawn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Peony Ants at Dawn

Peony ants at dawn go round,
in pinky, sugared murmur-mote;
they chitter-chap the petal-ground,
and dewlets drub their candy boat.

Hush, chick, heed hushbloom counsel cold:
the Paeonimyrx bites sweet men.
Its ambermandibles take hold,
and groom your dreams in sugar-pen.

Take up the thornablade of dawn,
your dewbright clippers click-click, clear;
bind buckle-bands and bloomplates on,
and mask your mouth with nectar gear.

Through scentfog foams a clicking queen,
the Rosy Ruck of Chitterly;
her brood in beetle-ballerine,
go tip-tap, tick-tack, tittery.

We met by peony's pink brim,
her sugar-sirens swarmed my sight;
I whirlwind-whacked on petal rim—
split saffron chime from chitter-bite.

Clack-clack! the thornablade went down,
scritch-scrunch! the broodline broke in two;
the queenling hissed a syrup frown,
and amber-ichor ached the dew.

Back through the hushbloom hedge I came,
with thornablade tucked cool and clean;
my elders poured a milkpet fame,
O bloom-brave boy! O garden-gleam!

Yet hush: the petals pulse with sound,
soft murmurlings adrift afloat;
Peony ants at dawn go round,
and I keep watch in petal-boat.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "oscilloscope lissajous bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Oscilloscope Lissajous Bloom

The lab-lights limned a humming room
Scopes whispered softly green
Oscillo-forest fanned its bloom
In lissajous between

"Heed phase-winds," murmured Elder Tech
That Bloom drinks steady hands
The Lissabloom will wring your deck
And snare your signal strands

I primed my trigger, tuned the sweep
The voltblade warm with hum
I donned the Faraseam for keep
And twirled a quivrum thumb

From trace to trace it upped its vine
Zzrr—ping!—a bloom of blue
A sineserpent forged of sine
With petal-phase of blue

It braided night with noisecurl glare
My probe-hand shook—kch-choom!
Its echo-eyes unspooled my air
A windowed, warbling bloom

I locked the drift with razor gate
Then phased the petals back
I swung my voltblade, clean and late
Across its lobe and track

It shivered, sheared—a gliss of light
Thrum-thwip! the petals tore
Serpent-sine toppled into night
A hush across the floor

I bore the quenched bloom’s nullsome core
Back through the humming beams
The Elder Tech loose-laughed once more
Bright shepherd of the beams

The lab-lights limned a humming room
Scopes whispered softly green
Oscillo-forest fanned its bloom
In lissajous between

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "civet note and drydown". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Civetnote and the Drydown

At scent-time all the flacons prowled,
They swish and spruzzle in the shelf;
The accordlings were amberhowled,
And sillage softly spilled itself.

“O spritzling, heed the Civetnote;
Its feral purr will fog your head.
Shun Drydown’s dusk, that muskermote;
Its hush can haunt,” the elder said.

I primed my plume of atom-spray,
My blotterblade of paper bright;
With bergbite, aldehiss array,
I paced the spice-lamp night forthright.

From murk of musk, the Civetnote
Came pad-pad, purring through the air;
The Drydown Wight in shadow coat
Trailed hush along the strands of hair.

I raised my blade; pssst—atom!—spritz!
The blotter whirred, a paper arc;
With spritz-crack, aldehissy blitz,
I cleft its purr apart from dark.

It fizzled, fumed; the muskermote
Went wan into a lemon white;
The Drydown drained; the Civetnote
Lay faint upon my skin, now white.

“O nose-born knight!” the elder sniffed,
“Your paper brand has tamed the beast!
Hoozah, Huzziff!” his whiskers lift;
We clinked the vials; feast was bright.

At scent-time all the flacons bowed,
No more they spruzzle on the shelf;
Accordlings cooed, no longer loud,
And sillage softly soothed itself.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Reglet and Furniture

By lamp and lead the presses purred,
and reglet lined the furniture;
the galleys gloomed, the quoins demurred,
and slugworms slept in signatures.

Take heed of Furniphage, my cub—
its gnasher gums crave iron gear;
The Reglegast will nip your nub,
and drakes of quoin creep grinning near.

He fetched his stick, a stickling bright
and quoin-key keen with click and clack;
he donned a dawnproof apron tight
and laced his leads in letterpack.

The platen chimed: tik-tak, tik-tik,
the formes went thrum and shiver-sure;
the galleys glowed with inky slick,
and reglets rang in furniture.

When through the chase-door slithered forth
the Furniphage with filcher-fur;
it chitter-chunked from south to north,
and sniffed at each inked signature.

Reglegast skirled behind the formes,
a skreek of nails on letterwood;
Quoindrakes uncoiled, clattering wild,
their gullet-glugs drank printer's blood.

He set his chase, he screwed the key,
clink-clank! the comp locked sure and square;
he sprung the stick at Reglegree—
skrawk-scritch! the case clamped down and square.

The Furniphage leapt, jaws ajar,
he feinted left, then planed it true;
with quoin-key twist and typer bar,
ka-chunk! he drove it cleanly through.

Back through the ink-mist strode the cub,
his apron specked with furnifuzz;
he bore the gnarled and gnomish nub
that once had chewed our furniture.

Huzzah, my sprig! now shop may purr;
the reglets rest in furniture;
let galley-glooms grow mild once more,
till leads and lamp-lit presses purr.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "old piton scar". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Old Piton Scar

By the old piton scar I stood
where cliffwinds whicker thin;
The chockstones chittered close like wood,
the rope-song skirred within.

Mind Gripfang, kin, the belay-wight,
old Granitefather said;
Shun Scrimshaw Cracks at sable light,
and Chokevine's rasping thread.

So I took up my clink-spoke axe,
my chalk and knurlèd gear;
I looped my cord through iron tracks,
and clicked the carabeer.

Out crept the Skreezard, scaly lean,
from that old piton seam;
Its peen-tooth grin was oiled with sheen,
its hiss a harrowed dream.

It clinked the scars with clack-a-clack,
and skirled the ropes askew;
My heart went drum, my hands went tack,
as chalk spun ghosty blue.

I set my cams in crackle-slot,
and sang a belay-psalm;
Then WHANG! my pick in pebbleshot,
bit true through scree and calm.

The Skreezard skreeked and slither-sank,
down past the piton bruise;
I coiled my cord, my knuckles dank,
and stowed the cliffside news.

Back by the old piton scar I
the cliffwinds whicker thin;
The chockstones hush their clatter-mar,
and rope-song sleeps within.

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tinsmith’s Stake-Song

At brimble dusk the tinsome looms
went scringe and skurl in copper vale;
the glimble stakes in starnish rooms
did whindle, whey, and hammer-wail.

“Beware the Stakesong, smithling dear,
its tittered tings will twist your will;
the Tinwyrm winds from near to near,
and clang-whish croons for blood to spill.

He took his starnsteel staking-rod,
he oiled the haft with soot and brine;
he hummed the smithsong, nod by nod,
to tune his nerve in anvil-shine.

Through slag-dens and scoria fen,
he stalked where rivet-vines entwine;
the murk went tink and tok again,
like drumlings tapping iron brine.

Then hush! the Stakesong sibil-sang,
a sizzle-steel along the slag;
the Tinwyrm’s scales went clang-a-clang,
its shadow cast a smelter-flag.

He set his soles on cinder crust,
he marked the beat: thud-clang, thud-clang;
with forge-born faith and tinker trust,
he drove the staking-iron bang.

The Stakesong broke to stutter-blank,
the Tinwyrm thrashed with glaum and grit;
Skree-skraw! went iron rivet shank,
as slaglight steamed and quenched its wit.

He wiped the stake on cinder moss,
and bound the scars with braided twine;
he bore it home through bloom and dross,
his heartbeat hummed in hammer-twine.

“You felled the Tinwyrm, child of spark,”
the elder laughed in coal-kissed pride;
“Your stake shall guard our gloaming dark,
its song shall keep the slagwinds tied.”

At brimble dusk the tinsome looms
went scringe and skurl in copper vale;
the glimble stakes in starnish rooms
did whindle, whey, and hammer-wail.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pietra dura inlay". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Intarsion

It was marble noon; velvet dust
went swish along the slate.
The jasper-sparks in gentle gust
went clink and scintillate.

Beware Intarsion, child of mine,
its grouty jaws that grate;
and shun the Lapivex's whine
that whirr and sibilate.

He grabbed his agate-wheel and glue,
The charcoal chalked the slate;
He stropped the carborundum true
and hummed to calibrate.

In muffish hush the shop-doors swung,
Skreet-scrape along the grate;
Out slithered Intarsion, tongue
went shick and osculate.

Its back was bands of onyxine
With fretted jasper plate;
Its eyes were saffrire, serpentine,
that tisk and titivate.

One marbleblade he set to spin,
Whirr-zip the rim sang straight;
He pressed and paced the pattern in,
Ker-chak—inciscreate.

Intarsion cracked to stony rain,
Went skitter skritch-skritch-skrat;
He framed the shards in stony grain
And sealed them—clack—thereat.

He bore the panel home at dusk,
The neighbors craned the gate;
His parent cried, O lapidusk!
And danced, “Congratulate!”

It is marble noon; velvet dust
Goes hush along the slate.
All opalant, the patterns, trussed,
Go clink and scintillate.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blue hour on snow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Blue Hour on Snow

The blue hour breathed upon the snow,
The hushgleam pooled in hollow lanes;
Through gloamfrost fields the slow winds blow,
And bluemote dusts the birch-bark veins.

Be wary of the Bleakloof, mine,
Its skreek is cold, its stare is cose;
It skirls along the fence of pine,
And gnaws the moon to mottled rose.

Take up the frostwick, keen and spare,
Your emberlamp and bramble-mail;
Bind boot to boot with twile-threaded care,
And learn the driftwind’s whispered tale.

I tread where blue-on-blue lies deep,
The snowskin sighs with scrinch and sough;
The spruce-lights tick and foxfires sleep,
While hushbells brim the frosted bough.

Lo, out the sleet-blue hedge it came—
The Bleakloof, bleak as midnight bruise;
Its mufflemouth made mumble-flame,
Its eyelids clicked with icebound fuse.

It skreeked skreer-skree through winter air,
Kra-krak the beak, and scrall went claw;
The stillness rang—a brittle flare—
And bluehour throbbed with thrum and awe.

I raised the frostwick, frost-cold bright,
It sang a steely shiver-sheen;
Down I went through velveted night,
And split the poise between its preen.

Scrish-scrash! it fell, a blursome heap,
Blue breath unrolled in ribbon-sighs;
The wind uncinched its winter-keep,
And starlets pricked the muffled skies.

I brought the frostwick home again,
My emberlamp with bluish glow;
"Be glad," cried hearth and kinnerein,
For blue hour breathed upon the snow.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "crosstie creosote scent". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Crosstie Creosote Scent

At gloam, the switchgrass whisper-bent
in cinders, soot, and shade;
Yard breathed crosstie creosote scent,
that tarry, twilight braid.

Beware the Taragrue, my sprout,
its clackclaw, clink, and glare;
the Sleeper-snake that sidles out
from ballast, oil, and air.

He hefted up his spikewrought bar,
a ranglet, rail-long keen;
and donned a lamp like low red star,
with hiss of kerosene.

In switchyard hush the sidings yawned,
skreek-scrapes stitched the cold steel;
out ooze-crawl, Taragrue tight-pawed,
its creosote-wet heel.

Clang-clong! the spikewrought bar he swung,
through breath of pitch and brine;
Skirl-snap! it reeled with tarry tongue,
and split the tie-line spine.

Back down the runnel tracks he trod,
all soot-smiled, slow, and still;
his pocket kept a grit-scrap clod,
yard-winds uncreaked their will.

At gloam, the switchgrass whisper-bent
in cinders, soot, and shade;
Yard breathed crosstie creosote scent,
that tarry, twilight braid.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Balancespring Collet

At gloam-o'clock the gearlings chimed,
and lathe-lamps hummed in brassy gloze;
The pivot-pips went clink and chimed,
while hairsprings wove to whisper-doze.

Mind Balancespring Collet, child;
Its clamp-maw warps the tidy time;
the Screech-o'-Scape with ratchets wild
and Nyctopinions that chime-chime.

I upped my tweezle-wits and loupe,
strapped mainspring-heart with silken thread;
my calipblade went clack-a-cloop,
and steadyears thrummed within my head.

Through cogwood lanes the tick-tocks trilled,
a whirrwind whisked the dust of brass,
when forth the Collet-creeper spilled
with clampsome bulk in brassy mass.

Its spindle-snout went skreek-skrak-skreek,
its balance-hairs uncoiled askew;
it sniffled oil with squeamish squeak
and swizzled seconds into stew.

I steadied heart and breathed in twos,
aligned the balance spring collet;
my tweezer-tips went tiktik—choose,
and locked it flush with snug-bollit.

The Collet-creeper coughed its clicks
and fell to pulse in peace and poise;
I brought it home to hush its ticks
and let the workbench breathe repose.

Now gloam-o'clock, the gearlings chimed,
and lathe-lamps lulled in brassy gloze;
the pivot-pips went meekly timed,
while hairsprings wove their whisper-doze.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Pantograph Arcing Blue

Pantograph arcing blue it sang,
The wireroads whistled to the sky;
Through rain and rail the rim-wheels rang,
And soot-sparks stitched the storming sky.

"Take heed the Pantagruff," he said,
"That arcs along the wirenet dire;
Its flitter forks are lightning-fed,
Its zizzle-breath is biting fire."

I donned my glasshelm, glove and shoe,
A groundling cloak I buckled round;
I gripped the breakerbrand of blue,
And timed the trackward thunder-sound.

Skreek-skrak! the trolleylines did buzz
As dusk unrolled its woolly plume;
The mastpoles hummed in switchback fuzz,
The crisp arc-crowns went vrumble-vroom.

Out slid the Pantagruff on high,
A clampish, crown-èd, copper kite;
Its splay-spar claws went zither-sly,
Its eyebright toggled cold with light.

I raised the breakerbrand and leapt,
"Krazzak!" the switchblade sizzled, sang;
We sparred along the sizzling weft,
And all the yarding railways rang.

Then through its clamp I cleft the loop,
Kerzakk! the crackle blew out blue;
It kinked and kited in a swoop,
Then sighed a long and smoky blue.

Pantograph arcing blue it sang,
Yet peace lay folded now above;
I bore my breakerbrand; it rang,
And momrail hummed with rail-born love.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration over Stubble

At gloamlight on the stubble-sward
The murmurlings made shadow-lace;
They whirr and skirl in whorlskein ward,
Black braid across the barley's face.

Ho child, said Eldermum, take heed:
That swarm is Gloamergast's gray cloak.
It lures with loop and listless speed
To sip your thought in soot and smoke.

Take chaffbrand bright and thresher-spear,
Bind windwise knots about your brow;
Wear stubbleboots, tread stook and sheer,
And light a hush within you now.

I strode the strawstrewn furrow-line;
The murmurlings went hush-whish-whirr.
Grain-glinters pricked the purple brine,
As duskbirds made a skirl and stir.

Out swolled the Murmurlord at last,
A sky-skein knotted into face;
Gloamergast exhaled pepper-blast,
Sharp skirr-skirr cut the rust-brown space.

Its whisperwings wrote loopèd lore—
Come drift, come drowse, come fold and float.
A thousand beaks spelled evermore;
Churr-churr went threading in my throat.

I bit the hush my Elderm taught,
And stilled my gaze to wheatseed-small;
Then sweeved the chaffbrand, ember-wrought—
A hush-flare sprang, a sooty fall.

The Murmurlord unknit its seam;
Black beads became but birds, then rain.
Sky's braid unspooled to ragged stream—
Skreek-skraaw, they fell like pecking rain.

I stubblestepped to hearth and hay;
Eldermum smiled with weathered eyes:
Your windwise knots held true today—
Now keep them when the pattern lies.

At gloamlight on the stubble-sward
The murmurlings make shadow-lace;
Yet mind the loops and hold your ward,
Black braid, but now a gentler face.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Pewter Inlay Ribbon

The pewter inlay ribbon gleamed
Along the bench of brad and burr;
It pewtreglinted, fine and seamed,
While cogs went whirr and pliers purr.

Beware the Ribbonwight, my child,
Whose rivet-teeth are cold as rain;
It tinsel-snarls the meek and wild,
And sips their metal-muddled brain.

Take up the seamlit measure-blade,
And knot the bracetwine with care;
Oil up the hinge-heart pivots made,
Let clink and chime your courage bear.

Wind on your wrists the metal-lace,
A pewter inlay ribbon, true;
The craftmoot charm of holdfast grace,
To bind what gnashes, nibs, and chews.

Hush—through the geargrove fog it came,
Skreek-skraw the spindle-panels sang;
Its eyes were twin blue brazier-flame,
Its rivet tongue went klang-a-klang.

The Ribbonwight unspooled a hiss,
And looped me in its filigree;
I felt the tinshade's strangler-kiss,
The shop-lights rang like hammered sea.

Then up I cast the measure-blade,
And crosswise cinched its thrumbling waist;
With pewter inlay ribbon swayed,
I sheared the knot; its grip unbraced.

Back through the geargrove, light by light,
I bore the loosening of fear;
The pewter inlay ribbon bright
Lay gleaming on the bench and near.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Chatterbrayer

It was lino-light; brayers rolled
In inky underlay;
They skritchled through the chatterfold
By grainling, gouge, and fray.

Mind, child, the Chatterbrayer's rasp
It skirls through ink too slick;
Its jitter-roller jolts your grasp
With clatter, clack, and click.

He primed his brayer, set his hand
A hush on paper lay;
He planed the lino, trued the band
To calm the fickle sway.

Through inkwell-woods he wandered mute
Where platen-thunders drum;
Past trundlepress and squeegling chute
Went thrum-thrum, hummer-hum.

From Raglin-ruts there sprang a shape
A skitter-roller grim;
The Chatterbrayer, jawed with jape
Went skreek and clack at him.

He twined his wrists and swept it clean
Skritch-scrunch the chatter seam;
A pressstroke-two, a pressstroke-keen
Hush-whew! the inkwaves gleam.

He lugged the stilling roller home
To studio and light;
They pinned the proof in lintel-foam
Oh pressfolk, print tonight!

It was lino-light; brayers rolled
In quiet underlay;
No skritchle split the chatterfold
The grainling kept at bay.

Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quarter‑Sawn Shimmer

In stickered stacks the shoplights swim,
Where quarter‑sawn shimmer now sighs;
The grain runs rife in rayflit rim,
and curls its catspaw to the sky.

“Beware the Grainwyrm,” Joiner said,
the Shimmerjack with fleckfire eyes;
Its knurls can nip the straightest thread,
and saps the steady and the wise.

“Take kerfkin, rasp, and oil your plane;
let edge be keen; befriend the plane.
Strop-strop, the steel went sizzle-flew,
as airy shavings skirled and flew.”

I chalked the line on oakheart board,
the shop went hush and hollow-thin;
A knurlshade slipped from stickered hoard,
with snarl and saw-saw, grin to chin.

The Grainwyrm’s rayflanks ripple-bright,
it hissed a szzrr of spliny spite;
Its pithy breath blew glue-cold night,
and pried my patient nerves alight.

I raised the jointer, edge aflare,
and met its rasping razor rush;
ZING-CLACK! went steel through knotted air,
THOK-THOK! the shuddered hush went flush.

The Shimmerjack fell skein by skein,
its flecks flew faint and drifted wan;
I carried home the singing grain,
while mallets murmured on and on.

In stickered stacks the shoplights swim,
where quarter‑sawn shimmer now grins;
The grain runs rife in rayflit rim,
and patient craft out-sings the sins.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "parrel bead on a gaff". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Parrel Bead on a Gaff

The tidelet twilled the tarry staff,
along the yawning gaff;
it clack-clack rolled by mast and chaff,
the parrel bead on gaff.

Beware the Beadboggle, my child,
its gnarlèd grin and laugh;
The Gaffghast prowls when gusts go wild,
it loves a slipping gaff.

I took my marly-marlin spike,
a beltfid bound in raff;
I swabbed my brace and steeled my pike,
to meet what haunts the gaff.

The moon made milk of bilge and foam,
the sheets went whirr and waff;
I strode the scuppers' clapperdome,
toward the duskward gaff.

Hush-hush, a hiss beneath the sail,
skreek-skraw, a scratchy quaff;
Beadboggle rose and raked the sail,
it hugged the heaving gaff.

Its neck was knotted, bead by bead,
its brail-lick tongue went "pfaf!"
The gaffrope screamed; the halliard plead—
I braced along the gaff.

I swung the marly-marlin spike,
click-crack! a snatchy staff;
I sent a sea-born strike with pike,
ker-thrump! it split the gaff!

The Beadboggle bit its bitter bead,
and gave a flurmy "pfaff";
Then slack it slumped, unstrung of greed,
and slid from groaning gaff.

I lugged the limp and beadish head,
to quarters, fore-and-aft;
My elder winked and softly said,
"Well gripped that grimmer haft."

The tidelet stills the tarry staff,
hush along the gaff;
No clack now spins by mast or chaff,
the parrel bead on gaff.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sourdough levain autolyse". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Levainth of Autolysm

When simmer dawn in scull'ry dim,
did whisk and whurl the soft flour-snow,
All gloamy crumbs went glimmer-grim,
and bowlside breezes murmured low.

Mind ye the Levainth, baker-kin,
the doughwyrm of Autolyse deep;
That foams its ferment, sly and thin,
and huffs a steamy spume so deep.

First sift the cloud-crumb, hush the bowl,
let water whisper, plip and pace;
Stir slow till glutenglow takes hold,
then rest in Autolyse’s soft grace.

Fold, stretch, and ploop the Levaine in,
it bubbles blorp and breathes its yeast;
Knead-knead, O fermerous within,
like moon-webs twined in wreath of yeast.

Take up your lame, the sliver-slice,
let whetstone sing its skirr-skirr song;
Set steamfang trap and scatter ice,
bid proofalong be patient long.

Out swelled the Levainth, foamy-fierce,
with pffft and prr and pop-plop stop;
Its gluten-greaves began to pierce,
our doughboard ranks to mop and slop.

I flashed the lame with slish-swash swerves,
criss-cross the feral seam-of-gleam;
Thrum-thrum the hearthheart roused its nerves,
and whomp! the steamfangs screamed a-gleam.

We shoved the beast to ember-cave,
pshhh-pshhh, the crust beat on and on;
It rose transformed, a hearth-born knave,
crack-crack—the bloom kept drumming on.

Now simmer dawn in old scull'ry dim,
and thanks the loaves that crackle low.
The Levainth sleeps in crusty rim,
and bowlside breezes murmur low.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "sashiko boro patch". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sashiko and the Ravelghast

By lamplight low the sashiko
through boro patch it passed;
The thrumwind hummed in selvage snow,
while lintlings nested fast.

"Beware the Ravelghast, my child,
that frets the warp at night;
The snagglemoths are meek and mild,
but it will gnash and bite."

I took my moon-needle in hand,
and inkblue sash of thread;
A crosshatch charm, a rice-grain band,
I looped it round my head.

The stitch-speech piped, soft tik-tak-tik,
the skritch of cotton snow;
I basted quiet counterstitch,
to net what frays below.

Through rummage-rooms and ragged lanes,
hush-warm the bobbins purred;
Then out the stovepipe-vent it came,
the Ravelghast unheard.

Its wings were ash of winter lint,
zzizz-zzuzz along the seam;
Its eyes were button-pits of glint,
it sucked the threads like steam.

I cast the sash in running knot,
snip-snap the loops flew tight;
A rice-grain ladder climbed its throat,
and bound its buzzing spite.

With cross-and-star I stitched it shut,
hush-hush the fabric sighed;
The Ravelghast unspooled to dust,
its zzizz grew small and died.

Needle held high, I heel-toed home,
the tatterfolk cried hey;
My mother stroked the patched-up loom—
"We stitch the night away."

By lamplight low the sashiko,
through boro patch it passed;
Where rips once fed, our patterns grow,
and lintlings nest at last.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "nixie tube warm glow". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Voltovore in the Nixie Glow

In nixie-tube warm glow they thrummed,
The digits winked and sang;
Through glassy gloom the filaments,
A fizzle-fuzzing tang.

Hark, hush the hum, my mentor said,
Shun Voltovore at night;
It sips the neon, nibbles codes,
And gulps your guiding light.

So wind your coiled resistorridge,
Prime catho-candle blade;
Clamp steadi-scope upon the bench,
And mask your eyes with shade.

Tick-tock the digits beat the dusk,
A copper-candle moon;
I scanned the racks of amber bones—
Whirr-whisper, soon-soon-soon.

Out slither-slinked the Voltovore,
Its nibber-nimbled bills;
It licked the lots of glowing loops—
Zzz-patter, crackle spills.

I raised my ohmblade—flash and flare—
Across its glassy snout;
Chop-chime! the nix-spark cleft the dark,
The feed reversed, fell out.

It flitter-faded, fizzing thin,
A ghost of orange air;
Then quiet rang; the numer-shelves
Breathed gentle, cool, and fair.

In nixie tube warm glow they thrum,
The digits breathe and beam;
We guard the light that guides our ghosts,
And mind the midnight gleam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cedar-Box Letter

Cedar-hush held the little box,
and letters slept within;
Sap-sweet and shadowed, scent of knots,
and dust of distant kin.

Beware, my child, the Cedarwight
that gnaws the ribboned seal;
It croons in grainy, gum-sap night
and chews the past to peel.

Go fetch your quill-guard, paper-helm,
your waxblade keen and clean;
Bind bold your heart in cedar-realm
and keep your senses green.

With tick-tack steps and thrum of thread
you slid the clasper's clasp;
The lid breathed out a timbered dread,
and sap-smoke filled your grasp.

Out swirled the Cedarwight of Grain,
a mothquill, mask, and maw;
Its letter-limbs went skrick and skrain,
it sipped at cedar-straw.

Then up you raised the waxblade bright
and scored the knotty seam;
Skitter-snap, you cleft its script-bite
and stilled the cedar-dream.

Back through the grain you bore the note,
its ink a dusk-blue brook;
The elders hummed a cedar-throat
and nodded, never looked.

Cedar-hush keeps the little box,
the letter wakes within;
Sap-sweet and steadied, peace in knots,
and dust of patient kin.

info.topic: letter kept in a cedar box

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "fiddle rosin dust". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fiddlewraith of Rosin Dust

At lamplight where the fiddles fret,
the rosin-dustlings drift;
They scrimble through the pegbox net,
and tickle tone and lift.

Take heed the Fiddlewraith, dear heart,
the Dustgrim, dry and keen;
Its bowteeth bite in scraping art,
its hush is harsh and mean.

Steer wide the Squeal-fox and the Scrape,
those gritglow ghouls of tone;
They wheeze "skree-skree!" through smoky drape
and rasp the ribs to bone.

He took his fiddle from the case,
its varnished ember-gleam;
He rosined up the bow with grace,
till strings began to dream.

He set his chin on maple shelf,
his fingers found their seam;
With pulse and pith he steadied self,
a timenotch on time.

Then through the rosin weather-veil,
the Fiddlewraith drew near;
It swirled in sifted whorls of pale,
zzzip-zzzip along his ear.

It flapped its chalky shawl and hissed—
skraw-skraw! skirl-a-shree-ah!
The grain-ghost grinned, the bridge was kissed,
the strings leapt skittishly.

With cutstroke, chop and shuffle-fling,
he split the dusted hide;
Scritch-crack! went horsehair on the string,
the wraith unwhirled and died.

He bagged the shed-of-silt it spilled,
that ashen ache of noise;
Homeward he paced, heart thrum-fulfilled,
soft-smiling, soot-stained soul.

At lamplight where the fiddles fret,
the rosin-dustlings drift;
They scrimble through the pegbox net,
and tickle tone and lift.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "plane iron camber". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Plane-Iron Camber

When lamplight pools on planed-up pine,
the shiver-shavings snurl and sing;
I heard the grainstone mumble-twine,
and chip-chow chittered—skring-a-kring!

“Beware the Camberwight, my blade—
the Tearout Tusk, the Rivel-Rip;
the Bevelbane that gnaws your grade—
it snatch-snarls rails and raises snipe.”

I clamped the planiron on stone
and honed a hum of burr-bright bloom,
set camber-curve to curl alone,
till whish-whirr whispered through the room.

I marked the mouth; I set the throat;
the shavervane began to glide;
with bench-breeze in my apron-boat
I skimmed the grainstream’s curly tide.

Out reared the Camberwight from knots;
through pithy caves it chitter-clacked;
its bevelgloom with splinter-spots,
and grainstorm breath that ravel-cracked.

I drew planiron, low and square—
Skew-snick! the shavervane sang clear;
I cambered true to slake the tear,
and zizz-zazz—grain went soft and clear.

Back brushed I through the shavings’ snow,
with curl-crowns bright upon the floor—
“O day of burrgleam! hush, O woe”—
the shop-ghosts kept their creaks no more.

When lamplight pools on planed-up pine,
Planelings prill in peace, and now sing;
the grainstone hums a kindly line,
and chip-chow giggles—skring-a-kring.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quenching brine hiss". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Quenching Brine Hiss

At dusk the brine went quenching hiss,
The moon smeared pale on tarry slips;
Cold gull-lamps blinked along abyss,
And hulls made slubbish, sloopy dips.

Mind well the briny Quenhiss-thing,
Its ssssh and sizzle slicks the piers;
With rimehook tongue and drift-net sting,
It skirls your wits to brackish fears.

I donned my foam-helmed cap of slate,
I strapped tide-iron to my side;
A brinebright gaff for hinge of fate,
Wave-buckle boots for seaward stride.

Through murkwharf lanes the bollards boomed,
The pilings clacked with crabby cheer;
The barnaclank of tide-things loomed,
As siltwinds sshhhed along the pier.

From kelp-curtains it coil-crept—hiss!
A lampblack length of quiver-spray;
The Quenhiss reared from brine-abyss,
Its eyes were tidestars blown astray.

I cast the net of skelded wire,
It lash-lapped tight with splish and smack;
My tide-iron found gurgle-fire,
With clitter-clatter cleave and crack.

The Quenhiss slackened, ebbing thin,
The quay-bells dunly thrummed hooray;
I stowed my fear like hooks within,
And trudged the plankways, salt with spray.

At dusk the brine made quenching hiss,
The moon lay pale along the slips;
The gull-lamps winked around abyss,
And hulls kept slubbish, sloopy dips.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "badger knot bloom". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Badgerknot Bloom

When bramblehour and badger-knot
did snarl and snebble through the gloom,
The burrow-bells went blim and blot,
and nettles nuzzled bloom.

Mind Badgerknot Bloom, bud of mine—
its bristle-vines will clutch and cling;
The Snarlsap, too, and Blusterbine,
they hiss and hobble-sting.

He took his knotknife, leaflight keen,
a briar-buckler, braid of bark;
He donned his hedgebuck helm of green,
and lit a pocket-spark.

Through thistle-thrum and thwittle-thwip,
by bogs that boggle, blub and bloom,
he stalked the snaggle-snaring drip
of sapsong in the gloom.

Badgerknot Bloom loomed from the loam,
a tangle-ruffled maw of moss;
its petal-paddles boomed—kaboom!
leaves clashed like clacking dross.

He feinted left, then looped the braid;
his knotknife kissed the coiling core—
skritch-skrack! the bindweed bonds unmade,
the root-rasp roared no more.

Back down the briars, bright as fire,
he bore the severed tanglespire;
"O sprimful day! Upraise the choir!"
the kettle chimed like lyre.

When bramblehour and badger-knot
lay loose, unlooped within the gloom,
the burrow-bells go blim and blot,
and nettles nuzzle bloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Krenovian Plane Throat

At venter dusk the bench was bare,
The shavings shivered thin and light;
The krenov throatling crooned for more,
With skritch and whisk it lured the night.

“Beware the Plane-Throat, child,” he said,
“The throatthing hunger hums in grain;
It nips the knurl of timid thread,
And skewers hearts along the plane.”

I honed a shard of cloudbright steel,
I wedged the sole with cedar tight,
I closed the throat to whisper-feel,
And chalked the grain for glider-sight.

Click-clack went clamps, then hush and hum,
The benchdog grinned in tung-oil gleam;
A swarfy scent of linseed rum
Drew thrum and thrip from shopfloor dream.

Out of the krenov throat it rose,
A Plane-Throat Wyrm with splinter mane;
It snarled skree-skree through knotted nose
And raked the rim of cedar vein.

I set my sorbel iron fast,
I slid it true along the seam;
Skritch-skrat! A ribbon, sleek and vast,
Uncurled a ghost of grainy steam.

Then swish and swack, I cleft its tune;
The Throat-Wyrm withered, pale at dawn.
I lipped the mouth to moon-slit June,
And skimmed the sled to autumn dawn.

At venter dusk the bench sits fair,
The shavings shimmer, thin and light;
The krenov throatling sleeps on air,
With skritch and whisk withdrawn to night.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Sencha Kyusu Drip

In kettle-gloam the kyusu drips,
soft sencha-scent goes sip by sip;
the leaflings lace the lacquered lip,
drip-drip, a hush of steeping tips.

Heed, kettle-heart, the Senchadrip;
it threads the steam with bitter grin;
eschew the scorch and scalding lip,
shun Slurmskulk's tug and Tannin-Sin.

Now warm the clay with whisper-swish,
prime pour to tame the tannin-glow;
set jadeleaf dreams within the dish,
then count three breaths of simmer-slow.

I peered along the steamskein lane,
through curling glass and window-glow;
when psshh-tchik pulsed the kettle-main,
the Drip-Kyusune slid below.

I tilted up the brewblade spout,
a swirl-slice sweep to flush its flow;
snick-snick went leaves in spinabout,
hiss-sip! the Senchadrip sank low.

Back through the room I kyusu-stepped,
cup-cradled calm where warmth ran mild;
Sip-sing! cried kin; their saucers swept,
and patience poured to palate, mild.

In kettle-gloam the kyusu drips,
soft sencha-scent goes sip by sip;
the leaflings lace the lacquered lip,
drip-drip, a hush of steeping tips.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Split‑Grade Enlargerburn

By safelight glow the trays stood stern,
The fix-fox fumes went churn and churn;
The splitgrade whispers creep and turn;
Shun the Split‑Grade Enlargerburn.

Heed granny Gray, the grainwright sage:
That contrastling will eat your range;
Its highlight-gnash, its shadow-fang,
Makes midtones thin and faces strange.

I took my tongblade, timer bright,
My filter-wheels of nought and five;
A dodgelash cut from cardstock night,
And trays that thrum with silver hive.

Enlarger whirred: click-tik, whirr-tak,
Its bellows breathed a dusty tune;
The safelight shushed; the shadows slacked,
The wetroom hummed a red maroon.

Out crept Split‑Grade Enlargerburn,
A contrast-wight, filament mane;
It peered through sprocket-eyes that churn,
And breathed in grainstorms, black as rain.

It flashed—zzzip!—fire across the sheet,
And bleached my shadows bone to bone;
I swung the nought-grade, soft and sweet,
To woo the face back into tone.

Then click! the timer bit: two, three;
I masked with dodgelash, swift and sure;
I cast the five-grade lash at sea
Of sky, to sear its glare to cure.

Enlargerburn gave ssshh and thrum,
It threshed its halo, blare by blare;
I flipped the lens to f-stop numb,
And burned its boast to balanced air.

Back to the tepid trays I came,
The silver sang a soft return;
The grainwright smiled through fixer-flame—
Shun the Split‑Grade Enlargerburn.
